questions.question: Question 1: Choose the correct pair matching with the diagram:

options.a: A: Loop diuretics, B: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
options.d: A: Thiazides, B: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

questions.explanation:
A is the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle and loop diuretics act on this part of the 
nephron. B is the distal convoluted tubule and thiazides act on this part of the nephron. Site of action of other diuretics: • Proximal tubule - carbonic anhydrase inhibitors • Collecting ducts and late distal tubule - epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) inhibitors and 
aldosterone antagonists

questions.question: Question 2: Diuretics acting on which part of the nephron have maximum efficacy?

options.b: Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.explanation:
Loop diuretics have the maximum efficacy. They act on the thick ascending loop of Henle by 
blocking Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter. Option A: Although 65% of Na+ is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule, diuretics acting here do not 
have maximum efficacy. This is because the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle has a great 
reabsorptive capacity and it absorbs most of the filtrate from the proximal tubule. Options C and D: Diuretics acting distal to the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle have 
limited efficacy because most of the reabsorption of Na+ (>90%) would have already occurred 
by the time the tubular fluid reaches there.

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following statements about furosemide is true? 202 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Acute pulmonary edema is an indication
options.b: Acts on the proximal convoluted tubules

questions.explanation:
Furosemide is indicated in acute pulmonary edema. It is a loop diuretic that acts on the thick 
ascending loop of Henle and inhibits Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter. 209 
Sold by @itachibot Loop diuretics have maximum efficacy amongst all the diuretics and are therefore called high 
ceiling diuretics. They can be given by both the oral and parenteral routes.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 70-year-old man with pulmonary edema is started on furosemide. Which of the following 
would you not expect after starting the drug?
questions.explanation: Furosemide causes metabolic alkalosis. The adverse effects of furosemide (loop diuretics) are: • Hypovolemia • Hyponatremia • Hypokalemia • Hypocalcemia • Hypomagnesemia • Hyperuricemia • Increased LDL-C and decreased HDL-C • Glucose intolerance - hyperglycemia • Ototoxicity

questions.question: Question 5: High ceiling diuretics are used in the treatment of all of the following patients except:

options.b: 35-year-old woman with a head injury and cerebral edema

questions.explanation:
High ceiling diuretics are not used in pulmonary hypertension. High ceiling or loop diuretics have diuretic properties as well as vasodilatory action. • Diuretic property - removing excess fluid in hepatic, renal, and cardiac diseases • Vasodilatory action - quick symptomatic relief of symptoms in LVF and acute pulmonary edema. 
They are also used for the treatment of chronic CHF. Pulmonary artery hypertension is a condition where there is increased pulmonary vascular 
resistance. Since nitric oxide is an important regulator of pulmonary vascular resistance, PDE5 
inhibitors like sildenafil, vardenafil or tadalafil are primarily used in the treatment of pulmonary 
arterial hypertension.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 65-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease was given a diuretic intravenously. 
Following administration of the drug, she developed tinnitus and diminished hearing. Which 
of the following drugs was most likely given?
questions.explanation:
Ethacrynic acid is the diuretic that was most likely given as it is commonly associated with 
ototoxicity. Ototoxicity occurs with rapid intravenous infusion and the hearing impairment and deafness are 
usually reversible. Ethacrynic acid should be used only in patients who are not able to tolerate other loop diuretics. 210 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: 203 
Sold by @itachibot Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors do not cause:
questions.explanation:
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors do not cause metabolic alkalosis. They cause metabolic acidosis 
due to increased bicarbonate excretion Option B: Increased bicarbonate excretion causes urinary alkalinization. Option D: Increased delivery of Na+ to distal tubules causes increased K+ excretion.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following can be administered intravenously?
questions.explanation:
Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that can be administered intravenously. It is 
indicated in the acute management of angle-closure glaucoma for the rapid reduction of IOP 
before surgery. The oral formulation is given for open-angle glaucoma. Options A and B: Brinzolamide and dorzolamide are available only as ophthalmic drops and used 
in open-angle glaucoma. Option D: Methazolamide is available as an oral formulation and used for open-angle glaucoma.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 30-year-old man joins a pilgrimage to a shrine at a mountain peak. At the summit, he 
develops tightness in the chest, associated with breathlessness and altered sensorium. Which 
of the following can be given for symptomatic relief?
questions.explanation:
The symptoms are suggestive of acute mountain sickness and acetazolamide can be given for 
symptomatic relief. It can also be used for prophylaxis.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient with a glioblastoma multiforme is started on mannitol as palliative therapy. Which 
of the following statements is false regarding its diuretic action?
questions.explanation:
Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. These drugs do not cause much change in the GFR. Osmotic diuretics cause extraction of fluid from the intracellular compartment resulting in the 
expansion of the extracellular compartment. The renal blood flow increases and renin release is 
inhibited. An increase in renal medullary blood flow removes NaCl and urea from the renal 
medulla thus reducing medullary tonicity. There is not much change in the total GFR.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of both feet and of breathlessness 
on exertion. After evaluation, she was diagnosed with congestive cardiac failure. Which of the 
following drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Mannitol is contraindicated in patients with cardiac failure. Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It acts by extracting water from the intracellular compartments, 
which results in the expansion of the extracellular fluid. This results in volume overload and frank 
pulmonary edema in patients with cardiac failure. 211 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient with hypertension is prescribed chlorthalidone. What would be the effect of this 
drug on the excretion of electrolytes?
questions.explanation:
Chlorthalidone is a thiazide diuretic which increases Na+ and K+ excretion and decreases Ca2+ 
excretion.

questions.question: Question 13: Thiazide diuretics are not used in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Thiazide diuretics are not used in the treatment of hyperlipidemia. They result in an increase 
in the levels of LDL, total cholesterol, and triglycerides. Option A: Thiazide reduces Ca2+ excretion and is used in the treatment of idiopathic 
hypercalciuria with nephrocalcinosis. Option C: They are also used in the treatment of edema associated with CHF, hepatic cirrhosis, 
and nephrotic syndrome. Option D: Thiazides are the mainstay for the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. They 
reduce the kidney's ability to excrete free water. They increase proximal tubular water absorption 
and block the ability of DCT to form dilute urine.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 45-year-old man with hypertension is prescribed chlorthalidone. Which of the following is 
unlikely to occur in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Hypocalcemia is unlikely to occur in a patient on chlorthalidone, a thiazide diuretic. Thiazide diuretics do not cause hypocalcemia. They result in hypercalcemia. Thiazide and loop diuretics share similar side effects except that loop diuretics cause 
Ca2+excretion (loop loses calcium) whereas thiazides retain Ca2+ and cause hypercalcemia. Other side effects of thiazide diuretics are: • Hypokalemia • Hyponatremia • Hypomagnesemia • Metabolic alkalosis • Hypercalcemia • Hyperuricemia

questions.question:
Question 15: A 42-year-old man in the nephrology ward has a GFR of less than 30mL/min, suggestive of 
severe renal failure. What is the best drug that can be given to him?
questions.explanation:
Metolazone is effective in severe renal failure (GFR<30ml/min). 212 
Sold by @itachibot Metolazone works primarily in the distal convoluted tubule, rather than the proximal convoluted 
tubule, and has little effect on GFR and can hence be used in patients with a reduced GFR. 
Indapamide is another thiazide diuretic that may be effective in severe renal failure.

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient has been on lisinopril since being diagnosed with hypertension last year. His blood 
pressure readings are quite high, and the doctor considers adding a diuretic. Which amongst 
the following would be the ideal add on drug?
questions.explanation:
Hydrochlorothiazide would be the ideal add-on drug. It is a thiazide diuretic and causes 
hypokalemia, which can counteract the hyperkalemia caused by lisinopril, an ACE inhibitor. Aldosterone causes Na+ absorption in the collecting duct and the distal tubule in exchange for H+ 
and K+. ACE inhibitors decrease angiotensin II levels and thereby, decrease aldosterone levels. 
Decreased aldosterone level causes K+ retention by reducing the exchange. Therefore, ACE 
inhibitors cause retention of K+. Diuretics that cause elevation of plasma K+ levels are not suitable for combining with ACE 
inhibitors. Potassium-sparing diuretics like spironolactone, eplerenone, and amiloride are contraindicated 
with ACE inhibitors.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 10-year-old boy is brought with complaints of vomiting and lethargy after swallowing 
several pills of his father’s medication. Serum electrolytes indicate hyperkalemia. Which of 
the following drugs can you rule out?
questions.explanation:
Indapamide can be ruled out as it is a thiazide diuretic that causes hypokalemia. The other drugs 
are potassium-sparing diuretics that cause hyperkalemia. K+ sparing diuretics work by 2 mechanisms: • Blocking the ENaC (epithelial sodium channel) • Triamterene • Amiloride • Aldosterone receptor antagonist • Spironolactone • Eplerenone • Canrenone

questions.question:
Question 18: 206 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following diuretics do not need to be present in the tubular lumen for 
pharmacological action?
questions.explanation:
Aldosterone antagonist acts from the interstitial side of the tubular cells. They do not have to be 
present in the tubular lumen for their action. Aldosterone antagonists enter the tubular cells from the basolateral membrane. They 
competitively inhibit the binding of aldosterone to mineralocorticoid receptors. 213 
Sold by @itachibot Thiazide diuretics, loop diuretics, ENaC inhibitors, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors have to be 
present in the lumen for its action. They are all secreted from the proximal tubule into the tubular 
fluid through the organic anion/ cation transport process. Osmotic diuretics reach the lumen via glomerular filtration.

questions.question: Question 19: Canrenone is a metabolite of:
questions.explanation:
Canrenone is a metabolite of spironolactone. Spironolactone is metabolized completely in the liver. It is also converted to an active metabolite, 
canrenone that is responsible for more than 50% of the spironolactone action. Spironolactone has 
a half-life of 1-2 hours while canrenone has a half-life of around 18 hours. Eplerenone is an aldosterone receptor antagonist similar to spironolactone and metabolized 
primarily by CYP3A4, but no active metabolites have been identified.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 52-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis develops ascites. What is the drug of choice for 
management?
questions.explanation:
The diuretic of choice in a patient with cirrhotic ascites is spironolactone. Spironolactone is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule 
and collecting duct of the kidneys. It causes a decrease in sodium reabsorption and potassium 
excretion in the distal tubule. As a result, spironolactone promotes sodium diuresis but maintains 
body potassium levels. Spironolactone is particularly helpful in edematous states caused or exacerbated by 
hyperaldosteronism such as in cirrhotic ascites.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is not a side effect seen in a patient receiving spironolactone?
questions.explanation:
Aldosterone antagonists cause hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and not metabolic alkalosis. 
They inhibit H+ secretion in parallel with K+ secretion thus resulting in acidosis. Other side effects are: • Hyperkalemia • Gynecomastia • Renal insufficiency.

questions.question:
Question 22: 207 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is not an indication for amiloride use?
questions.explanation:
Amiloride is not used in the treatment of calcium nephrolithiasis. The condition is sometimes 
treated with thiazide diuretics but not amiloride. 214 
Sold by @itachibot Amiloride is a K+ sparing diuretic that acts by inhibiting the epithelial Na+ channels. The various 
uses of amiloride are: • Edema/hypertension - usually in combination with thiazides • Lithium-induced polyuria - blocks lithium transport into collecting tubules • Cystic fibrosis - aerosolized amiloride enhances mucociliary clearance; acts by inhibiting Na+ 
absorption from epithelial surfaces and increasing hydration of secretions • Liddle syndrome - hyperactive epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) activity is reduced

questions.question:
Question 23: A 35-year-old man with asthma presents with complaints of increased urination. The doctor 
checks that he has been taking theophylline and counsels that it could be a side effect. What 
is the mechanism of action causing diuresis?
questions.explanation:
The diuretic effect of theophylline is due to the blockade of adenosine (A1) receptors. Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug that acts by - • Inhibition of phosphodiesterase enzyme (PDE) • PDE3 inhibition - relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle • PDE4 inhibition - inhibition cytokines and chemokine release, which leads to a decrease in 
immune cell migration and activation • Blockade of adenosine receptors inhibits bronchoconstriction, however, blockade of A1 receptors 
in the glomerular afferent arteriole and PCT causes diuresis. • Activating enzyme histone deacetylase-2, which is responsible for its anti-inflammatory action 215 
Sold by @itachibot Anti-Arrythmic Drugs
